title: 1 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 15.

questions.question: Who reigned over Judah in the eighteenth year of Jeroboam king of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Abijam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:1 states that Abijam reigned over Judah in the eighteenth year of Jeroboam.

questions.question: How many years did Abijam reign in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Three years
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:2 says Abijam reigned three years in Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: Abijam's heart was perfect with the LORD his God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:3 explains that Abijam's heart was not perfect with the LORD his God.

questions.question: For whose sake did the LORD give Abijam a lamp in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: David's
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:4 states that the LORD gave him a lamp in Jerusalem for David's sake.

questions.question: What was the name of Asa's mother?
questions.correctAnswer: Maachah
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:10 identifies Asa's mother as Maachah, the daughter of Abishalom.

questions.question: True or False: Asa removed his mother Maachah from being queen because she had made an idol.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:13 confirms Asa removed Maachah from being queen because she made an idol in a grove.

questions.question: How long did Asa reign over Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: 41 years
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:10 states Asa reigned forty and one years in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What kind of people did Asa remove from the land?
questions.correctAnswer: Sodomites
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:12 says Asa took away the sodomites out of the land.

questions.question: Which king built Ramah to block entry to Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Baasha
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:17 states Baasha king of Israel built Ramah to block entry to Judah.

questions.question: Who did Asa send gifts of silver and gold to in order to break the league with Baasha?
questions.correctAnswer: Benhadad king of Syria
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:18-19 shows Asa sent silver and gold to Benhadad king of Syria to break his league with Baasha.

questions.question: What was the result when Benhadad hearkened to Asa's request?
questions.correctAnswer: He attacked Israel's cities
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:20 says Benhadad sent his captains to smite cities of Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Asa was diseased in his feet in his old age.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:23 mentions Asa was diseased in his feet in old age.

questions.question: Who succeeded Asa as king of Judah?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoshaphat
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:24 states Jehoshaphat, Asa's son, reigned after him.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Nadab the son of Jeroboam began to reign over Israel in the ______ year of Asa king of Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: second
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:25 says Nadab began to reign in the second year of Asa king of Judah.

questions.question: Who conspired against Nadab and killed him?
questions.correctAnswer: Baasha
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:27-28 states Baasha conspired against and killed Nadab.

questions.question: What was the reason given for Baasha destroying the house of Jeroboam?
options: Because of Jeroboam's sins that made Israel sin
Because of a prophecy from Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: Because of Jeroboam's sins that made Israel sin
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:29-30 explains Baasha destroyed Jeroboam's house due to Jeroboam's sins which provoked the LORD.

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with forgiveness and asks how to live with a heart perfect before God. Based on 1 Kings 15:3-5, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Walking in obedience to God's commands shows a heart perfect before Him
Ignoring past sins leads to a perfect heart before God
Relying on human strength is key to a perfect heart
Doing only what is easy pleases God
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in obedience to God's commands shows a heart perfect before Him
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:3-5 teaches that Abijam's heart was not perfect because he walked in sin, unlike David who did right by God and obeyed His commands faithfully, except one instance. This shows that obedience to God's Word is essential for a heart perfect before Him.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 15:11-13 teach us about dealing with sin and temptation within family life?
options: Removing idols and sinful influences from the family honors God
Accepting family faults is the best way to love
Only public sins need to be addressed
questions.correctAnswer: Removing idols and sinful influences from the family honors God
questions.explanation: As Asa removed idols made by his mother Maachah (1 Kings 15:13) and took away the sodomites and idols from the land (15:12), this shows the importance of confronting sin in the family and removing sinful influences to live righteously.

questions.question: When facing opposition at work or in ministry, what practical lesson about perseverance can we learn from Asa's response to Baasha's siege in 1 Kings 15:17-22?
options: Trusting God and seeking alliances can overcome obstacles
Retreating and giving up is the best option
Ignoring problems will make them disappear
Acting alone without help ensures success
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God and seeking alliances can overcome obstacles
questions.explanation: Asa responded to Baasha's building of Ramah by making a treaty with Benhadad (15:18-19) and then used the materials from Ramah to build other cities (15:22). This exemplifies trusting God through wise action and alliances to overcome trials.

questions.question: A believer asks how to live with humility and contentment in old age despite physical infirmities. What does Asa's experience in 1 Kings 15:23-24 teach us?
options: Continue faithful service even when physically weak
Avoid responsibility when old or sick
Ignore health challenges and pretend all is well
questions.correctAnswer: Continue faithful service even when physically weak
questions.explanation: Though Asa was diseased in his feet in old age (15:23), he still had a lasting legacy and was buried with his fathers (15:24). This teaches perseverance and faithfulness despite trials and infirmities.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 15:26, 29-30 warn us about the consequences of leading others into sin through our actions?
options: Leading others into sin provokes God's anger and judgment
Our actions have no impact on others' faith
Sin only affects the individual sinner
God ignores repeated sin if we repent occasionally
questions.correctAnswer: Leading others into sin provokes God's anger and judgment
questions.explanation: Nadab and Jeroboam's sins caused Israel to sin and provoked God's anger (15:30), leading to Baasha destroying Jeroboam's house (15:29). This highlights the responsibility to live righteously to avoid causing others to stumble.

questions.question: A fellow believer wants to grow in generosity and stewardship. What example from 1 Kings 15:15 can you share about giving to God's work?
options: Asa brought dedicated silver, gold, and vessels into the house of the LORD
Asa kept all treasures for himself
Only the king's treasures should be given to God
Giving to God is optional and only for the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: Asa brought dedicated silver, gold, and vessels into the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:15 shows Asa honoring God by bringing dedicated treasures into the temple, teaching the importance of generous giving and stewardship in supporting God's work.

questions.question: How does Asa’s removal of his mother Maachah from queenhood (1 Kings 15:13) teach us about maintaining integrity and holiness in leadership?
options: Leaders must remove sinful influences to uphold godliness
Family ties should override moral standards
Leadership is about personal gain regardless of righteousness
Idols are acceptable in leadership if tradition allows
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must remove sinful influences to uphold godliness
questions.explanation: Asa removed his mother because she made an idol (15:13), demonstrating that godly leaders must maintain holiness even when it involves difficult personal decisions.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Kings 15:12-14, even though Asa did not remove all high places, his heart was perfect with the LORD all his days.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:14 explicitly states that although Asa did not remove the high places, his heart was perfect with the LORD throughout his life, showing God values sincere devotion.

questions.question: True or False: Baasha king of Israel reigned peacefully with Asa king of Judah, and there was no war between them according to 1 Kings 15.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 15:16 and 15:32 clearly state there was war between Asa and Baasha all their days, so peaceful reign was not the case.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand the importance of spiritual discipline and removing sinful practices. Based on 1 Kings 15:12, what action did Asa take that models this?
options: He took away the sodomites from the land and removed idols
He accepted all practices to maintain peace
He ignored sinful practices as long as he was king
He allowed idols to remain to please the people
questions.correctAnswer: He took away the sodomites from the land and removed idols
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:12 shows Asa actively removed sinful influences, demonstrating commitment to holiness and spiritual discipline.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 15:18-20 illustrate the use of resources and wise stewardship in times of conflict?
options: Asa used temple and royal treasures to make an alliance for protection
Asa hoarded treasures and refused to share
Asa wasted resources on building useless structures
Asa ignored strategic planning during war
questions.correctAnswer: Asa used temple and royal treasures to make an alliance for protection
questions.explanation: Asa gave silver and gold from the house of the LORD and the king's house to Benhadad to break Baasha's league (15:18-20), showing wise use of resources to secure God's protection.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with the challenge of leadership integrity. How does 1 Kings 15:27-29 show consequences for leaders who lead by evil example?
options: Baasha conspired and killed Nadab, fulfilling God's judgment
Leaders who sin face no consequences
Leadership sins are private and do not affect the nation
questions.correctAnswer: Baasha conspired and killed Nadab, fulfilling God's judgment
questions.explanation: Verses 15:27-29 describe Baasha killing Nadab and destroying Jeroboam's house as a consequence of Jeroboam's sin, showing that God holds leaders accountable.

questions.question: How can 1 Kings 15:22 encourage believers in serving the church community when facing setbacks?
options: Turning obstacles into opportunities by rebuilding and repurposing resources
Giving up when plans are thwarted
questions.correctAnswer: Turning obstacles into opportunities by rebuilding and repurposing resources
questions.explanation: Asa took stones and timber from Ramah (15:22) to build Geba and Mizpah, showing how setbacks can be used to strengthen the community.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 1 Kings 15:9-11, Asa did what was __________ in the eyes of the LORD, as did David his father.
questions.correctAnswer: right
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:11 states Asa did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, following David’s example of obedience and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 15:6-7 teach us about perseverance through ongoing conflict and trials?
options: War between Rehoboam and Jeroboam continued all their lives, showing the need to trust God in long-term trials
Conflicts always end quickly if we pray
Avoiding conflict is the only way to please God
questions.correctAnswer: War between Rehoboam and Jeroboam continued all their lives, showing the need to trust God in long-term trials
questions.explanation: Verses 15:6-7 describe continual war during their reigns, encouraging believers to persevere and trust God despite prolonged difficulties.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand the importance of sharing God’s truth and the consequences of sinful leadership. Based on 1 Kings 15:34, what would you say?
options: Walking in sin like Jeroboam leads the whole nation astray
Sinful leadership has no effect on the people
Only private sins matter, not leadership sins
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in sin like Jeroboam leads the whole nation astray
questions.explanation: Baasha walked in Jeroboam’s sinful way (15:34), causing Israel to sin, showing how leaders must set godly examples to protect the people’s faith.

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 15.

questions.question: Who reigned in Judah during the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam's reign over Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Abijam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:1 states that Abijam reigned over Judah in the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam's reign.

questions.question: What was the name of Abijam's mother, and from which notable ancestor did she descend?
questions.correctAnswer: Maachah, daughter of Abishalom
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:2 identifies Abijam's mother as Maachah, the daughter of Abishalom.

questions.question: Which king's heart was described as not perfect with the LORD, unlike David's, due to walking in the sins of his father?
questions.correctAnswer: Abijam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:3 explains that Abijam walked in all the sins of his father and his heart was not perfect with the LORD as David's was.

questions.question: For whose sake did the LORD give Abijam a lamp in Jerusalem and establish his son after him?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:4 shows that God granted Abijam a lamp in Jerusalem for David's sake, to establish his lineage.

questions.question: Which king is noted for having done what was right in the eyes of the LORD, except for one specific sin involving Uriah?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:5 highlights David's overall righteousness except for the matter involving Uriah the Hittite.

questions.question: True or False: There was continuous war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam throughout their lives.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:6 explicitly states there was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all their days.

questions.question: How long did Asa reign in Jerusalem according to 1 Kings 15?
questions.correctAnswer: 41 years
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:10 notes that Asa reigned for forty and one years in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What radical religious reform did Asa enact regarding idols and his mother Maachah?
options: Removed idols and deposed Maachah for making an idol
Built new high places and appointed Maachah queen
Made Maachah a priestess and encouraged worship of Baal
Restored idols and honored Maachah as queen
questions.correctAnswer: Removed idols and deposed Maachah for making an idol
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:12-13 describe Asa removing sodomites and idols, and deposing his mother Maachah because she made an idol.

questions.question: Despite Asa's reforms, which religious sites were not removed, yet his heart was considered perfect with the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: The high places
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:14 states Asa did not remove the high places, but his heart was perfect with the LORD all his days.

questions.question: What strategic move did Asa make to counter Baasha king of Israel's siege at Ramah?
options: Sent treasures to Benhadad of Syria to break his alliance with Baasha
Launched a direct attack on Baasha's capital
questions.correctAnswer: Sent treasures to Benhadad of Syria to break his alliance with Baasha
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:18-19 describes Asa sending silver and gold to Benhadad to induce him to break his league with Baasha.

questions.question: Which cities were captured by Benhadad’s forces after heeded Asa’s request against Baasha's kingdom?
options: Ijon, Dan, Abelbethmaachah, and all Cinneroth with Naphtali
questions.correctAnswer: Ijon, Dan, Abelbethmaachah, and all Cinneroth with Naphtali
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:20 details the cities Benhadad captured at Asa’s request.

questions.question: What was the consequence for Baasha king of Israel after Benhadad's attack on his cities?
options: He stopped building Ramah and dwelt in Tirzah
questions.correctAnswer: He stopped building Ramah and dwelt in Tirzah
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:21 states Baasha left off building Ramah and dwelt in Tirzah after Benhadad's attack.

questions.question: What does the repeated phrase 'all that he did are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings' reveal about the biblical historiography in this chapter?
options: It emphasizes the existence of official royal records external to this text
It indicates the chapter is a complete historical account
It shows the author’s uncertainty about the events
It suggests the events are fictional
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the existence of official royal records external to this text
questions.explanation: Verses like 1 Kings 15:7, 15:23, and 15:31 mention the chronicles, indicating the narrative is based on official records.

questions.question: Who succeeded Asa as king of Judah after his death?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoshaphat
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:24 records that Jehoshaphat, Asa’s son, reigned in his stead.

questions.question: How is the sin of Jeroboam described as affecting Israel in this chapter?
options: He made Israel sin and provoked the LORD to anger
He brought peace and prosperity to Israel
He established true worship of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He made Israel sin and provoked the LORD to anger
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:30 explains Jeroboam's sins caused Israel to sin and provoked God's anger.

questions.question: Which king conspired against Nadab and killed him to take over the throne of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Baasha
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:27-28 describe Baasha conspiring against Nadab and killing him to reign instead.

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 15, how did Abijam's heart compare to that of David regarding his relationship with the LORD?
options: His heart was not perfect with the LORD as David's was
His heart was more devoted than David's
He was completely obedient like David
questions.correctAnswer: His heart was not perfect with the LORD as David's was
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:3 states that Abijam's heart was not perfect with the LORD his God, unlike David's heart. This shows a contrast in devotion and obedience, consistent with themes of human sinfulness and the ideal heart God desires (cf. 1 Samuel 13:14, Acts 13:22, Psalm 51:10, Jeremiah 17:10).

questions.question: What reason does 1 Kings 15 give for the LORD preserving Abijam's line and establishing Jerusalem?
options: Because of David's righteousness and faithfulness
Because Abijam was a great warrior
questions.correctAnswer: Because of David's righteousness and faithfulness
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:4-5 explains that the LORD preserved Abijam's line and Jerusalem for David's sake, highlighting the covenant faithfulness of David. This reflects God's covenantal mercy and faithfulness, as seen in 2 Samuel 7:12-16, Psalm 89:3-4, Romans 11:29, and Hebrews 6:13-18.

questions.question: How long did Asa reign over Judah according to 1 Kings 15?
questions.correctAnswer: Forty and one years
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:10 states that Asa reigned forty-one years in Jerusalem. This long reign allowed for significant religious reforms, echoing God's desire for covenant faithfulness (cf. 2 Chronicles 14:1-2, Ecclesiastes 12:1, Joshua 24:15, Deuteronomy 5:33).

questions.question: What major religious reform did Asa undertake concerning his mother Maachah?
options: He removed her from being queen because she made an idol
He built an idol for her
He sent her to a foreign land
questions.correctAnswer: He removed her from being queen because she made an idol
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:13 records that Asa removed his mother Maachah from her position because she had made an idol in a grove, which he then destroyed. This reflects the biblical condemnation of idolatry (Exodus 20:3-5, Deuteronomy 12:2-3, Psalm 115:4-8, 1 Corinthians 10:14).

questions.question: Despite Asa's reforms, what religious practice was not fully removed during his reign?
questions.correctAnswer: The high places
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:14 states that the high places were not removed during Asa's reign, though his heart was perfect with the LORD. This tension reflects the gradual nature of religious reform in Israel and the ongoing struggle against syncretism (cf. Judges 2:6-10, 2 Kings 17:9, Hosea 4:13, Isaiah 1:13).

questions.question: What was Asa's response to Baasha king of Israel building Ramah to block access to Judah?
options: He sent silver and gold to Benhadad to break his alliance with Baasha
He prayed and fasted for deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: He sent silver and gold to Benhadad to break his alliance with Baasha
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:17-19 describes Asa sending treasures to Benhadad king of Syria to form an alliance against Baasha, showing political strategy and trust in God's providence. This illustrates God's sovereignty over nations (cf. Proverbs 21:1, Isaiah 37:36, Daniel 2:21, Romans 13:1).

questions.question: What was the outcome after Benhadad attacked the cities of Israel following Asa's alliance with him?
options: Baasha stopped building Ramah and lived in Tirzah
Baasha defeated Benhadad and continued building
questions.correctAnswer: Baasha stopped building Ramah and lived in Tirzah
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:21 states that Baasha ceased building Ramah after Benhadad's attacks and dwelt in Tirzah. This shows divine intervention through geopolitical events (cf. Exodus 14:13-14, Isaiah 10:5-7, Psalm 46:10, Acts 17:26).

questions.question: Which king reigned over Israel after Nadab, as recorded in 1 Kings 15?
questions.correctAnswer: Baasha the son of Ahijah
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:28-33 details that Baasha killed Nadab and reigned over Israel. This shows the consequences of sin and political instability, consistent with God's judgment in biblical history (cf. Judges 9, 1 Samuel 15, Psalm 75:7, Romans 13:4).

questions.question: How is the sin of Jeroboam described in 1 Kings 15 and its effect on Israel?
options: Jeroboam’s sins caused Israel to sin and provoked God to anger
Jeroboam led Israel into perfect obedience
Jeroboam’s sins had no effect on Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam’s sins caused Israel to sin and provoked God to anger
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:30 explains Jeroboam’s sins caused Israel to sin and provoked the LORD to anger. This reflects the biblical doctrine of corporate sin and covenantal responsibility (cf. Exodus 32:7-10, Ezekiel 18:20, Romans 1:18-32, James 5:16).

questions.question: What does Asa do with the treasures dedicated by himself and his father?
options: He brings them into the house of the LORD
He uses them to pay mercenaries
questions.correctAnswer: He brings them into the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:15 states Asa brought the dedicated silver, gold, and vessels into the house of the LORD, showing reverence and honoring God. This aligns with biblical teaching on giving and worship (cf. Exodus 25:1-2, 2 Chronicles 29:12-15, Malachi 3:10, Hebrews 13:16).

questions.question: What was the nature of the conflict between Rehoboam and Jeroboam mentioned in 1 Kings 15?
options: There was war between them all their days
They formed a lasting peace treaty
questions.correctAnswer: There was war between them all their days
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:6 records continual war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam, reflecting the ongoing division and struggle in Israel’s monarchy, consistent with the consequences of disobedience and division (cf. 1 Kings 12:16-24, Psalm 46:9, Isaiah 9:6-7, John 10:10).

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 15 reveal about the kingship succession following Asa’s death?
options: Jehoshaphat his son reigned in his stead
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoshaphat his son reigned in his stead
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:24 states that Jehoshaphat, Asa’s son, succeeded him. This continuation of David’s line points to God’s covenantal promise and messianic lineage (cf. 2 Samuel 7:12-16, Matthew 1:6, Luke 1:32, Acts 2:30).

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 15, what sin is attributed to Nadab king of Israel?
options: He did evil in the sight of the LORD, walking in his father’s sinful ways
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil in the sight of the LORD, walking in his father’s sinful ways
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:26 states Nadab did evil and continued his father Jeroboam’s sins, illustrating the biblical theme of generational sin and covenant disobedience (cf. Exodus 20:5, Numbers 14:18, Ezekiel 18:2-4, Romans 6:23).

questions.question: What was the duration of Baasha’s reign over Israel according to 1 Kings 15?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty and four years
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:33 records Baasha’s reign lasted 24 years in Tirzah. This long reign amid persistent sin shows God's patient judgment and the consequences of idolatry (cf. Judges 16:30, 1 Kings 11:14, Psalm 90:10, Romans 2:4).

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 15 say about Asa’s health in his old age?
options: He was diseased in his feet
He was taken to heaven without dying
questions.correctAnswer: He was diseased in his feet
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:23 notes Asa was diseased in his feet in old age, reflecting human frailty and the reality of suffering even among godly leaders (cf. Psalm 71:9, 2 Corinthians 12:7-10, James 5:14, Revelation 21:4).

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 15 describe Baasha’s actions towards the house of Jeroboam?
options: He destroyed the entire house of Jeroboam, leaving none alive
questions.correctAnswer: He destroyed the entire house of Jeroboam, leaving none alive
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 15:29 describes Baasha wiping out Jeroboam’s family, fulfilling God's word through Ahijah the Shilonite about judgment for sin. This highlights divine justice and fulfillment of prophecy (cf. Deuteronomy 13:12-18, 2 Kings 9:7-9, Jeremiah 25:15-29, Matthew 23:37-39).
